questions.text: A scar excision followed by reconstruction with a split skin graft was performed on the forearm of a  28-year-old man. The survival of the graft during the first 48 hours will be mainly dependent on ________.
questions.solution:
Skin grafts survive by imbibition during the first 48 hours. 

The stage of imbibition is the first stage of graft uptake during which the graft draws nourishment from the plasma exudate at the host site (by simple diffusion). After this inosculation and revascularization take over. 

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: A patient with a leg injury was treated with a skin graft as shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this type of skin graft?

choices.text: Degree of contraction is dependant on amount of dermis in graft
Healing with abnormal pigmentation are more common.
Meshing grafts improve their ultimate cosmetic appearance

questions.solution:
The given image shows a meshed, split-thickness skin graft. Split grafts are meshed to expand the surface area that can be covered but it does not improve the cosmetic appearance.

Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Less dermis also translates into a better chance of graft survival. Thin split grafts have a low primary contraction, high secondary contraction, and high reliability of graft take. However, they tend to heal with abnormal pigmentation and poor durability.

Type of graft Split-thickness graft Full-thickness graft
Composition Epidermis + part of the dermis Epidermis + full dermis
Cosmetic appearance Relatively poor Good (texture and pigmentation are better matched)
Graft take/survival High chance of survival Poor (long healing time and vascularization)
Contraction Lesser primary contraction and more secondary contraction More primary contraction and lesser secondary contraction
Use Can cover large areas of defects For areas where least contraction (finger) or best cosmesis (face) is desired

questions.text: A 34-year-old man sustains facial burns and is being planned for reconstruction with a skin graft. Which type of graft should he receive to achieve a better cosmetic appearance and minimal contraction?
questions.solution:
The patient should receive a Wolfe graft to achieve a better cosmetic appearance and minimal contraction. Wolfe grafts are full-thickness skin grafts that are used for small areas of skin replacement where good elastic skin that will not contract is required (such as fingers, eyelids, and facial parts).

  Full-thickness skin graft (Wolfe) Split thickness skin graft (Thiersche)
Structure Epidermis + complete dermis ± fat Epidermis + part of dermis
Donor site location Post auricular, supra/infra-clavicular. 
Never axillary		 Thigh > buttocks
Donor site wound Must be sutured Requires only dressing and can be reused
Recipient site Must be well vascularised. Small area May be inadequately vascularized. Larger area (achieved by meshing)
Graft features
Durability High Low
Contracture Primary > secondary High secondary contracture
Uptake Require more care to ensure uptake High-reliability
Cosmetic result Good Poor (abnormal pigmentation)

Option B: Partial-thickness skin grafts or split-thickness grafts are called Thiersch grafts. They consist of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. They tend to heal with abnormal pigmentation and result in suboptimal cosmetic appearance.

Option C: Composite grafts are grafts that contain skin and fat or skin and cartilage. They are often taken from the ear margin and useful for rebuilding missing elements of the nose, eyelids, and fingertips.

Option D: Blair-Brown grafts are a type of intermediate thickness split skin graft.

questions.text: The most common cause of skin graft failure is ____

choices.text: Poor quality of the recipient bed

questions.solution:
The most common cause of skin graft failure is hematoma under the graft, where the blood clot is a barrier to contact of the graft and bed for revascularization.

Other causes are shearing or movement of the graft on the bed, infection, poor quality of the recipient bed, and characteristics of the graft itself, such as thickness or vascularity of the donor site.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: A 20-year-old lady sustained extensive burns over her left forearm for which a split-thickness skin graft was planned. During surgery, after obtaining a skin graft from the anterior thigh, the patient became hemodynamically unstable and a transplant to the forearm could not be completed. What would you do with the harvested graft?

choices.text: It must be discarded and fresh graft harvested before repeat surgery
It can be stored for up to 2-3 days at +4°C in saline
It can be stored for up to 2-3 weeks at +4°C in saline
It can be stored for 2-3 months at +4°C in saline

questions.solution: The harvested graft can be stored at +4°C in refrigeration after wrapping it in a sterile gauze pad moistened with saline. The process of harvesting and storing skin grafts is called skin banking. Skin banks store grafts using various methods. Most commonly preferred is to store the graft for up to 2-3 weeks at +4°C.

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to a skin graft harvested from the post-auricular area?
questions.solution:
Graft harvested from the postauricular area is a full-thickness skin graft. As it involves harvesting the complete dermis donor site needs to be sutured following harvest.

questions.text: A child is being prepared for a Millard’s repair as seen in the image. The factors influencing the development of his condition are all except __________________.
questions.solution:
Vitamin A deficiency during pregnancy is not a factor influencing the development of cleft lip/palate. Millard’s repair is the most common surgical repair of cleft lip and is usually performed between 3 to 6 months of age.

The cause of orofacial clefting is felt to be multifactorial. Factors that likely increase the incidence of clefting include increased parental age, drug use and infections during pregnancy, and smoking during pregnancy.

questions.text: The given image shows a forearm flap harvested for the reconstruction of the oral cavity of a 45-year-old patient with squamous cell carcinoma. Identify the type of flap.
questions.solution:
The picture shows a radial forearm free flap. Fasciocutaneous radial forearm free flap is the most common free flap used in head and neck reconstruction. 

A flap defines the tongue of tissue whereas a pedicle is used to describe the base or stem with the vascular supply.

In a free flap, the blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site. Other Eg for free flaps: free fibular flap, DIEP flap (Deep inferior epigastric perforators)

Option A: Axial flaps are much longer and are based on known blood vessels. Eg: Latissmus Dorsi flap, TRAM (Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap.

Option B: An islanded flap is that in which the axial blood supply is swung round on a stalk.

Option D: A random flap includes three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters. Eg: V-Y plasty, Z plasty, Limberg, or rhomboid flap.

questions.text: The flap shown in the picture is which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a serratus anterior flap. The serratus anterior flap is a highly reliable flap with a consistently long pedicle. Its anatomy permits coverage of complex wounds. The underlying rib can be included as a myoosseous flap to expand the versatility of this flap.

questions.text: The image shows a surgical technique used to release Dupuytren's contracture. Which of the following statements is true regarding this?

choices.text: It can also be used in the surgical management of keloid scars and contractures
It reorients the direction of the central wound by 90 degrees
Triangular flaps created using 60 degrees can lengthen the scar by 50%
It is a type of local advancement flap

questions.solution:
The image shows a typical example of a Z Plasty.

It is a type of transposition flap that incorporates qualities of both advancement and rotation flaps. Z plasty is used for the lengthening of linear scars. It is best used in releasing simple contractures.

Usually, all the limbs are of equal length and ideally, the angle between them is 60°. Two triangular flaps are raised. Theoretically, a 60-degree angle flap will result in a 75% increase in the length of the scar and a 90-degree reorientation of central wound.

Angles smaller than 60 degrees are easier to transpose but result in less lengthening and realignment of the scar to less than 90 degrees. Angles larger than 60 degrees should be avoided because the force required to transpose the flaps increases markedly, making the closure of the wound difficult. 

Relative contraindications to Z-plasty include patients with keloids and hypertrophic scarring tendencies.

questions.text: A truck driver undergoes a Limberg flap operation using a random flap for recurrent pilonidal sinus infections. What is the generally accepted safe and reliable length: width ratio for this type of flap?
questions.solution:
The Limberg flap is a type of random flap and the safe and reliable length:width ratio for the random flap 3:1.

Random pattern flaps have a blood supply based on small, unnamed blood vessels in the dermal-subdermal plexus, as opposed to the discrete, well described, directional vessels of axial pattern flaps. As random flaps have a variable blood supply, they need an adequate base (width) to survive.

The rhomboid (Limberg) flap involves creating a skin flap with two opposing angles of 60° and 120° at the corners, forming a rhomboid shape positioned directly next to the defect. The design allows the flap to be rotated into the defect, with the donor site closed primarily, ensuring minimal distortion to the surrounding tissues. This method is especially useful in areas like the gluteal region, where complex closure techniques help achieve optimal results.

questions.text: A free flap is used to resurface a tendoachilles defect in a 58-year-old chronic smoker. As a first-year surgical resident, you are asked to monitor the flap for venous occlusion. Which of the following should you be looking out for?
questions.solution:
The first sign of venous occlusion in a free flap is increasing warmth.

Clinical signs of arterial and venous compromise in a free flap:

Clinical Sign

 Arterial Compromise Venous Compromise

Color

 Becoming paler Increasingly reddish or purplish

Temperature 

 Becoming cooler Becoming warmer

Tissue turgor  

 Reducing Increasing

Capillary refill time

 Becoming slower  Becoming faster

Pinprick bleeding

Increasingly sluggish

Quickening (and darkening)

Note: Venous and arterial compromise may coexist, and one may lead to the other.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the flap given in the image.

choices.text: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
Free TRAM based on superior and inferior epigastric artery
DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
Lower Abdominal Fat based inferior epigastric vessels

questions.solution:
The given image showing only skin and fat moved to the chest is suggestive of a deep inferior epigastric artery perforator flap (DIEP), based on the deep inferior epigastric artery.

DIEP is a variant of TRAM flap and free flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest. A microvascular technique is used in which no muscle is taken and the perforating vessels are dissected out.

As the muscle is spared in DIEP, there is a reduced risk of abdominal wall weakness and its associated complications. 

Other options: 

Options A and B: The pedicled TRAM flap is based on the superior epigastric artery and the free TRAM flap is based on superior and inferior epigastric arteries (supercharged TRAM flap); however, the given image depicts a deep inferior epigastric artery flap. In TRAM flaps: 

  • The skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest.
  • It provides good cosmesis and bulk since it has a soft tissue consistency similar to the breast.
  • Disadvantages include epigastric bulge, partial flap loss, fat necrosis, abdominal wall weakness, and hernias.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who underwent a skin-sparing mastectomy a year ago has returned to your clinic to discuss her options for breast reconstruction. All of the following are options to consider except:

choices.text: A TRAM flap provides the best cosmetic result than LD flap
An LD flap provides adequate bulk of breast tissue
Reconstruction may be delayed or immediate
Capsular contraction is a dreaded complication of silicone implants

questions.solution:
An LD flap does not provide the bulk required and is usually used along with an implant. It is based on the thoracodorsal pedicle. It is an axial flap. 

Transverse rectus abdominus myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on superior epigastric or inferior epigastric or both (supercharged TRAM). Skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest. It provides good cosmesis and bulk. An implant is usually not required.Since the rectus abdominis muscle is excised in the procedure, it can lead to abdominal wall weakness and hernias.

The timing of reconstruction may be immediate or delayed. Impediments to immediate reconstruction include insufficient theatre time and a lack of experienced reconstructive surgeons. In addition, the patient is likely to need post-op radiotherapy, then a delayed reconstruction using a flap often gives better results.

The easiest type of reconstruction is using a silicone gel implant under the pectoralis major muscle. Capsular contraction is a dreaded complication of silicone implants.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with osteosarcoma of the mandibular ramus is planned for resection and reconstruction with a flap. The flap used most commonly in mandibular reconstruction is based on which of the following vascular structures?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used osseous flap for mandibular reconstruction is the fibular free flap. The fibular free flap is based on the peroneal artery and vein, and the blood supply to the foot should be investigated before harvesting this flap.

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient suffering from alcoholic cirrhosis receives a healthy liver from his biological son. What is this type of transplant known as?
questions.solution:
Transplant of an organ/tissue from a son to a parent is an example of an allograft.

An allograft is transplant of cells/tissues/organs from a genetically non-identical donor of the same species.

Isografts are allografts in which cells/tissues/organs are transplanted from a donor to a genetically identical recipient. (monozygotic twins)

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Type  Definition
Orthotopic

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. Diseased organ is removed. Eg: heart, lung, liver, intestine
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. Diseased organ is left in place. Eg: Kidney, pancreas
Auxiliary transplantation Partial tissue from the donor is used which acts as temporary support for the recipient's injured organ, which remains in place. Eg: left lobe of liver
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person. 
Allotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same species. 
Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.
Isograft Transfer of organ or tissue within genetically identical individuals. Eg: Identical twins

questions.text: What incision would you make to excise a lesion on the bridge of the nose, in order to cause minimal scarring?
questions.solution:
A horizontal incision should be taken as the relaxed skin tension lines (Borge's lines) at the bridge of the nose are horizontal.

Aligning a surgical incision or excision with skin tension lines results in minimal tension across the closure of the defect. This leads to optimal scar formation and minimizes wound contraction.

Skin tension lines reflect internal tension within the skin and are produced by the parallel alignment of connective tissue of the dermis. Several different skin tension lines have been described. Borge's lines which are also called relaxed skin tension lines are most useful to guide surgical incision. These are often confused with Langer's lines.

Langer's lines, also called cleavage lines are topological lines drawn based on the shape of wounds on cadavers. These were not intended as a guide for surgical incisions and they do not always correspond to the best orientation of skin tension and often run perpendicular to skin folds. On the face, these two sets of lines often run at right angles to one another.

questions.text: A plastic surgeon performs an upper eyelid reconstruction using a tarsoconjunctival flap for a patient who underwent a sebaceous gland carcinoma excision. What is the maximum tissue loss for which a primary repair would have sufficed?
questions.solution:
Defects comprising <25% of the upper eyelid can generally be closed primarily in pentagonal approximating fashion.

For defects involving 25–50% of the upper eyelid, lateral canthotomy and cantholysis can be performed.

Defects more than 50% need proper flap cover.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-week-old baby to the pediatrics OPD, with a lesion on his abdomen which has been growing in size since birth. On examination, the lesion is red, nodular, and blanches on pressure. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Local resection with carbon dioxide laser
En bloc excision with skin grafting

questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of infantile hemangioma. Only monitoring of the lesion is required as in 50% of cases, complete involution is seen by 5 years of age.

Hemangioma growth frequently peaks before the first year, and then the lesions enter the involuting phase. The involution phase begins in 50% of children by 5 years of age and in 70% by 7 years of age. It continues until 10 years of age.

Indications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining to the location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to large hemangioma over eyelid).

Treatment options include:

  • Beta blockers - oral propranolol
  • Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids
  • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine - for steroid-resistant lesions
  • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser
